div.p: A DECLARATION OF THE AFFLICTIONS AND PERSEcution of the Protestants in the Marquisate of SALVCE, belonging to the Duke of SAVOY.
SHEWING THE FAITH and Constancie of two Martyrs, put to death for Religion, in the said Marquisate, the 21. of October. 1619.
Also other Letters sent to the KING, from the reformed Churches in FRANCE, now assembled at LOVDVN.
With an Edict made by the French King, the ninth of Nouember last past: wherein the Prince of CONDE is declared innocent, and thereby enlarged of his imprisonment.
Translated out of French.
LONDON, Printed for Ralph Rounthwaite. 1620.

div.head: A LETTER VVRITTEN BY THE PROTESTANTS in the Marquisate of Saluce, belonging to the soueraigntie of the Duke of Sauoy, to the Ministers of the Church of Geneua; containing a Declaration of their persecution, and the faith and constancie of two Martyrs put to death in the said Marquisate for Religion: The 21. of Octob. 1619. by a Iudgement pronounced against them by the Inquisition, and the Senate of PIEMONT.
div.p:
SIRS, the Church in the Marquisate of Saluce, in her birth and aduancement hath encountred with many difficulties, and hath endured thousands of afflictions, & now lately for an accomplishment of her persecution, hath enioyed the crowne of Martyrdome. Peter Marchisy, a Notary of Aceil, in the vally of Maire, a man of good meanes touching worldly substance, & one that had aduanced & furthered the reformed Religiō in that place, saying prayers there in their meetings, & cōducting the Church, was committed to prison in the moneth
of Iune last past, by the Gouemor of Dronier, & from thence brought before the Inquisition of Saluce, for Religion. After him Sergeant Maurice Mongie also of Aceil, who all his life time had serued his Highnes in the Warres, for the same cause was put into prison about the beginning of September, as hee sought to procure the others deliuerance. Iudgement to die being pronounced against them both, because they cōfessed that they had assembled, & were present with those of the Religion at prayers, and were (as they termed them) Apostates, and persisted in the reformed Religion; After his Highnes departure into Sauoy, for the the receiuing and entertainment of the Princesse of Piemont; Vpon the 21. of October, they were both hanged in Saluce, about foure of the clocke in the morning, the Monkes all that night hauing earnestly laboured with them to forsake and deny the Religion, whom they most constantly refused, and withstood: Marchisy was first led to the Gallowes, who constantly went to his death. They would not suffer him to pray vnto God, nor once speake to the people: for the Executioner stopt his mouth, & one of those that conducted him to the Gibbet still beat him with a Cudgell. His last words were these, I see the heauens open, and behold the Angels attending for me. Where vnto a Monke that stood vnder the Gallowes, made answere and said, Those are the Diuels
that stay for thee in hell, wicked and damned wretch that thou art. The executioner still moued him to deny the Religion: but he dyed most constantly and faithfully. Mongie was brought forth after him, who cryed out, saying, Be of good courage, companion, wee haue wonne the victory: and so ioyfully without feare went to his execution: hee likewise was not permitted to pray vnto God, nor to say any other thing, but onely that hee was well knowne in the Prouince of Piemont and Daulphinois, by all men, to be of an honest and good conuersation, and that he died willingly, seeing it was for the name of God. They were both suffered to hang naked vpon the Gibbet vntill night, and they were laid in a Cart, and their bodies carried and buried in a ditch in the way to Turin. The Bishop was present at that spectacle sitting in his Carroche; the people beholding the same with many weeping teares. Thus in the space of halfe an houre, our Church obtained the honour to haue two Martyrs. We hope that it will increase by their ashes, and that their innocent bloud will be a means of Gods mercy toward vs. There was not any Counsellor nor Attourney, that durst once defend or speake in their cause. It is true, that they protested that there was no reason in their Iudgement, and that they ought not to be put to death, but that they durst not write so much: one of our Deputies that was at Turin,
to speake for them, and to declare their innocencie, hardly escaped from beeing committed by commandement of the chiefe President Manon, & from bearing them company in like sort. VVe begin again the armie of Martyrs, which the mercy of God, and the peace of the Church had restrained, and discontinued for a time. You shall see, if the death of these two faithfull Christians, will become the life of this Church. Those that are yet liuing of our Church, are all in danger of death. A poore Wife of one of them is yet in the Inquisition, & by the voice of the common people is already in the fire: wee dayly expect her martyrdome. All the rest of the faithfull are banished, in great feare and doubt to lose both their liues and goods; for we are no more assured of our liues, then those two that are already put to death. All our brethren are massacred in our persons. You shall heere see nothing but our teares, and weeping: but though wee haue lost our friends, and our goods, we haue not lost our faith, nor our hope; and now in the time of this furie and outrage of the enemy, God particularly sheweth his power. The day before these our two brethren were deliuered out of this earthly prison, Iohn Virell also made an escape, and got out of prison: The rest of the prisoners were seduced by torments and threatnings to recant. Their faith hath failed them, and by that meanes obtained their liberty
in this world. We recommend our selues vnto God, and to the prayers of the Church: And are

closer.signed: Your most affectionated brethren, and seruants, the faithfull members afflicted in the Marquisate of Saluce, & in their names.
closer.dateline: From our common banishment, the 25. of October. 1619.

div.head: A LETTER WRITTEN TO THE FRENCH KING, BY THE ASSEMBLY OF the reformed Churches in France, and the soueraignty of Bearne, permitted by his Maiestie to assemble together at LOVDVN.
With an Oration made vnto the said King, by the Lord Marquis de la Moussay, at Compeigne, the 23. of October, 1619.
div.p:
SIR, the principall and speciall duty wherevnto we acknowledge our selues to be bound, at our assembling heere together in this place, is to render and yeeld most humble thanks vnto your Royall Maiestie, for the fauor which it hath pleased your Grace to grant vnto vs to assemble together, vnder the bounty thereof, to finde out remedies for our sore and smarting wounds. To the which end wee
haue sent vnto your Maiestie, the Lord Marquis de Moussaye, and de Chasteauneuf, together with Messieurs Banage, de Chazeray, and Tessier, to certifie vnto your Maiestie the great ioy, and entire feeling that we haue in our hearts of your most princely fauour; and withall to present vnto the same, the certain and true assurance of our humble subiection, and most faithfull obedience.

But, (may it please your Maiestie,) feeling in our soules and consciences, the true & sincere affections of this obedience and subiection, so liuely rooted and ingraffed therin, we could not without extreme griefe, behold our selues exposed vnto so many iniuries, and contrarie to your Maiesties will and intent, see your Proclamations and Decrees violated and infringed in all places, and in diuers manners, by those that hate vs onely for our Profession, although that by it, besides the lawes of nature, we are taught to obey our King for conscience sake. Therefore we are imboldned hereby to present vnto your Maiestie, our iust supplications and requests, grounded vpon your Proclamations, Decrees, and Declarations of your will and pleasure, and such as are most necessarie for our support and maintenance, which we most humbly beseech your Maiestie to vouchsafe to reade, and fauourably to giue your Princely answere therevnto, that beeing maintained and supported
by your Royall authoritie, we may liue secured, vnder the benefit of your gracious Edicts, and thereby haue better meanes to yeeld that most humbleseruice which is due & owing vnto your Royall Maiestie.

closer.signed: By your most humble, and most faithfull seruants and subiects, the Deputies of the reformed Churches in France, and the Soueraigntie of Bearne, assembled by your Gracious permission in Loudun.

div.head: AN ORATION MADE TO THE KING BY THE DEPVTIES OF THE REFORMED Churches in FRANCE, &c. assembled together in LOVDVN.
div.byline: Pronounced by the Lord Marquis de Moussay, at Compeigne, the 23. of October, 1619.
div.p: SIR, it is much, and most exceeding great honour giuen vnto vs, to haue the means at this day, to declare and shew vnto your Maiesty, the most humble thanks, which we yeeld vnto the same, in that it hath pleased your Grace, to giue and grant liberty vnto your subiects of the reformed Religion, to assemble together by their Deputies, from all the parts and soueraigne resorts of your Kingdome.

The first duty (may it please your Maiestie) being assembled as they are, they haue thought and esteemed it to be their parts, to giue vnto your said Maiesty, the true assurance of their loyall subiection, obedience, and fidelitie.

Which is, and shall alwayes remaine & be as firme and inuiolable in their hearts, vowes, and resolutions for your Maiesties seruice, as it hath already appeared, and bin manifested in their fore-passed actions.

Which we beseech your Maiestie, most humbly to beleeue concerning vs, and withall to continue the effects of your Royall bounty towards vs, whereof we dayly receiue so many fauours, that wee are forced to acknowledge and confesse, that God by that meanes onely preserueth our estate.

The same Bounty, and Princely Clemency, moueth vs at this time to let your Maiestie vnderstand our iust complaints, to our no small and insupportable griefe: but the liuely feeling of our mischiefe presseth vs therevnto, and that which is most insupportable, is to see and behold, and that in so many places, and against your Maiesties will, and Princely intent, the Edicts, and Proclamations of K. Henry the Great, your Father of most famous memory deceased, granted vnto vs, and since his death, by your Maiestie so oftentimes confirmed, to bee broken and disanulled.

Which is the cause that now most humbly we prostrate our selues at your Maiesties feet, with all humilitie, to beseech the same, that you would bee pleased strictly to command the entire obseruation of your good will and bounty towards vs to bee maintained and vpholden:

In such manner, that your Maiestie being the liuely Image of God on earth, your sacred commandements declared by Edicts, Proclamations, Letters and Commissions, in our fauours and behalfes, may bee religiously executed, and the contradictions repressed in all places of your obedience.

Which (it may please your Maiestie) to be aduertised, we do not desire only for our particular interest: but specially for the preseruation of publike tranquillitie, that the same may bee happily continued vnder your Royall authoritie; wherein our support, maintenance, and securitie onely consisteth.

Which will giue and procure vnto vs a greater meanes, to shew forth the effects of the obedience, that we owe vnto your Maiestie, both by Diuine & humane Law; from the which we can by no earthly power be dispenced withall, and wherein wee know our selues not to be inferiour to any, touching the most dutifull obedience of Subiects for your Maiesties seruice: most humbly beseeching your Maiesty, to receiue our Requests comprehended in this first

Schedule which we present vnto you, containing but seuen vrgent & most necessarie Articles for our welfare and preseruation.

Our hope (most puissant Prince, & our soueraigne Lord) is, in your Bounty & soueraigne Iustice, for the granting of our requests, and of your fauourable answere to our supplications; most humbly beseeching your Maiestie, to command so speedie a dispatch thereof, that it may come vnto our hands before the Assembly be dissolued.

In whose name, as also of all your loyall subiects of the reformed Religion, we once againe protest to be, and inviolably to continue your most humble and most obedient Subiects and Seruants, and freely, willingly, and couragiously to imploy our goods, honours, and liues, in your Maiesties seruice, and for the greatnesse and increase of your Princely Crowne and Regall honour.

div.head: AN EXTRACT OF THE ACTS AND Articles of the generall Assembly of the reformed Churches of France, and the soueraigntie of Bearne, now vnder the Kings Authoritie gathered at Loudun, in Touraine, neere Saumur.
AN EDICT MADE THE NINTH OF NOVEMBER. 1619.
div.p:
LEVVIS by the grace of God, King of France and Nauarre, To all such as shall these presents see, Health. The disorders not long since past in this Kingdome, haue made it knowne but too much, how farre was stretched the ambition and licentiousnesse of such, who for the honour they had to be neere vs and hold vnder vs great Offices and Power, had so farre abused our Name, and Authoritie, to their priuate ends, as if God had not giuen the courage, and strength to punish them, and
prevent the miseries, & calamities, which did threaten this State, it is likely they had brought it vnto a great and lamentable confusion.

And amongst other euils, by them procured, was the imprisonment and detention of our most deare and most beloued Cousin, the Prince of CONDE, first Prince of our Bloud, and first Peere of France; To whose liberty, as of it selfe most considerable, before we would fully resolue, we would be carefull exactly to informe our selues, of all the causes where vpon they had taken a pretence for his detention. Wherein we could finde none other, but the cunning and wicked purposes of such as to the ruine of our State would needs adde the ruine of our said Cousin, and of some other Princes and great Ones in this Kingdome: As also of another side, hauing found that the whole carriage and actions of our said Cousin, haue alwaies beene for the establishing and strengthning of our Greatnesse, and Authoritie, as his duty is; Wee haue thought good to giue him by these presents a publike testimony thereof. Wherefore, by the aduice of our Councell, which did assist the Princes of our Bloud, and other Princes & highest Officers of our Crowne, out of our owne meere motion, full power & Royall authoritie; We haue pronounced and declared, pronounce and declare by these presents, vnder our own hand and great Seale, That we hold our said Cousin the Prince of CONDE, innocent and guiltlesse of all such things as they would haue laid to his charge, and debase his Honour
and Reputation, whereupon they had coloured his imprisonment, and so abolished, reuocated and disanulled, abolish, reuocate and disannull all Letters, Declarations, Proclamations, Verdicts, Sentences and Iudgements, if any there be against our said Cousin, that could hinder, or be of any preiudice vnto him, from the day of his detention, vnto this present; As also we haue declared, and doe declare, all Informations, Depositions, and Inquiries therupon made, & other Acts therof depending, to be as none, and of none effect: Which Letters, Declarations, Proclamations, Verifications, Sentences, Iudgements, & any such Acts and Instruments, Wee command and will haue put out and taken away from the Offices and Records of all our Courts of Parliament, or any other places, where they shall be found, and all to be suppressed, and the memory thereof wholly quenched and abolished, as of a thing neuer done. And desiring graciously to deale with him, as the ranke of his Birth, and his Affection to our seruice doth inuite vs thereunto; We will, and Our pleasure is, that our said Cousin may & shal enioy & vse all his charges & gouernments, with all the Rights, Prerogatiues & preeminences vnto his ranke belonging, fully as he did before his imprisonment and detention. Therefore doe we straightly charge our trusty & wel-beloued Counsellors, holding our Courts of Parliament, that they cause these presents to be read, published and registred, and of the contents in them, our said Cousin to haue and enioy the full scope; causing
all troubles and impediments thereunto contrary to cease. And further do we command & straightly enioyne our Attourney Generall, to sue & require their enregistration, all other businesses ceasing & left behind. For such is our will and pleasure. In witnesse whereof vnto these presents signed with our owne hand, we haue caused our great Seale to bee opposed. Giuen at Fontainebelleau the 9. of Nouember, in the yeere of grace 1619. and of our Raigne the 10. Signed Lewis; and lower, By the King, & lower, Delomeny, Secretary of State; and sealed with the great Seale of France and Nauarre.

Afterwards, these were read, published & enregistred in the Court of Parliament, hauing to that purpose heard the Kings Attourny Generall, who did so require. Wherevpon the Court hath ordained that Autenticall copies therof shal be sent to the Bayliwicks, Seneschalships, & inferior Iurisdictions of the extent of this Court, there to bee read, published, & registrated at the sute & diligence of the substitutes of the Attourny Generall; vnto all whom the Court doth command to do it, & certifie the Court therof within a moneth: And further doth decree, that al writings contrary to these Patents shalbe suppressed; Prohibiting al persons to haue or keep any of them; & if any are found with them, the Court decrees they shall be apprehended at the sute of the Attourny Generall to answer it, & vnder goe such paine as reason shall require. Giuen in the Parliament of Paris, the 26. of Nouemb. 1619. Signed, Dutillet.

div.head: A friendly and ioyfull Congratulation made in the name of the Subiects of FRANCE, vpon the ioy by them conceiued of the Prince of CONDE his releasement out of prison, granted vnto him by the KING.
div.p:
WIth exceeding ioy (gracious Prince) wee salute you, as the third Branch & Stock of the Princely House of Burbon; the bright shining light of France: The true Character of Royal Maiestie, a haughty spirit shewing as high as a Cedar of Libanon, which like another Alexander neues conceiued or imagined any other but great matters, who at the age of 16. yeeres ouer came the Medarians, a spirit farre surpassing for eloquence & magnanimity the haughty spirit of Iulius Caesar: and much excelling the spirit of Pompey, for constancie and valor. Hauing vnderstood, that by the Royall pleasure of the Kings Maiestie, you haue left that ominous place, which caused an eclipse of your Greatnesse vnto our eyes: We haue therby conceiued exceeding great ioy, to behold and see you placed again in the Throne of glorie, thereby to re-obtaine your free and pristinate libertie: That we are perswaded that fortune hath past ouer the Riuer of Eurotas, to inhabit and dwell heere among vs: and that both heauen and earth are agreed together, in signe of ioy, to make vs heare the pleasant melodie of Lutes, & other instruments, together with
an Angelicall harmony, sounding Canticles and praises giuen vnto God for so great a happinesse. Pliny teacheth vs to be better pleased and contented with the enioying or your presence, then with all the gold and siluer that may bee gotten and digged out of the most rich Mynes of Europe: for that in the presence of a vertuous man, we receiue the flower of the bodie by contemplating his beautie, & the fruit of the soule by his actions. Wee know not the want of the force and violent heat of the Sunne-beames, but when they are in a manner hidden, and with-held from vs, by thicke mists, or darke clouds. The depriuing of our sights from the honor of your presence, hath made vs acknowledge the Greatnesse and Excellencie of your merits, which shall neuer depart out of our hearts, no more thē your praises shal be wanting in our mouths. These words are not the simple words of Grunius, of whom S. Hierome speaketh: but a publike and common voice; which as Pliny saith, concerneth the particular, for that the Oracle of God soundeth in the mouth of the world, and the heauens doe not yeeld more copious and variable ecchoes in seuerall places, then the voice of all men in generall doth, which speaketh not by hickcocks with the tongue tyed, nor certaine times like Psaphons bird. This ioy and contentment awaketh the people of France out of their slumber of griefe, caused by your absence. As Themistocles
was raised out of sleepe by imaginarie Triumphs; the rehearsall of your rare vertues, are as Nectar and Ambrosia to the most haughty Spirits of France. And as Antalcides saith, we cannot sufficiently aduance and extoll the merits of a Hercules, for that glory and commendation are the svveet paps of vertue, and the nourishing milke thereof. To cause the honour of your merits melodiously to sound; it behooueth vs rather to borrow some more learned and eloquent tongue, then that of Pindarus and Demosthenes, sith that at the report of the merits of your actions, both heauen and earth take pleasure in the sweetnesse thereof; and your flourishing actions being eleuated to the highest point of exaltation, all things of necessitie must prostrate themselues at the feet of their merits: as it is said, that in Sicile no man may hunt vpon Mount Aetna, because of the sweetnesse and great sauour of the Violets that are thereon, which makes the dogs to lose their sent. So our spirits are far too weake, to flye ouer the cloud of your Valour. The actions of the most valourous resemble Aeneas Buckler, which represented the whole defence of the Romane Empire, but not all the greatnesse and Maiestie thereof: And if, (as Labotus of Lacedemonia saith) that mens speeches and words should be proportionable to the thing which they expresse; How dare we take the same in hand, before the pens of so many
learned Persnages, when as Protigenes durst not draw a line before Apelles? Neuerthelesse, being thereunto moued and pricked forward with the winde of your prosperities, we wil take pen in hand to doe it, although the honour of so great a Prince can not be sustained, nor maintained by a simple pen; because honour is to be spred abroad and enlarged by the merits of a vertuous Prince. It is said, that there is nothing more excellent, then that which is void of vice; vertuous Prince resemble. Plutarcks Mountaines, whose tops being most high, and reaching to the cleere and bright ayre, are not subiect to any clouds, mists and dewes. To write & shew forth your merits (most generous Prince) we had need of as many learned pens, as there were Painters, to paint Venus and Alexander: Apelles painted her picture, Pergoteles did graue it, and Lysippus imbossed it; but our imperfect hands are not fit to be ranked among such excellent workmen: No, it must not be our hands that shall paint or set forth your praises: but your owne vertues, within the obiect of their beauty, will drawe their owne proper Image: as the Cyrian virgin Lala drew her owne picture, beholding her selfe in a glasse. And among al the vertues that shine in you, true Frenchmen with white Ensignes & Scarfes haue noted, (as most singular and excellent) the fidelitie and sacred vow, by you made for the obedience, and preseruation of the greatest
King, and most worthy of life, on whom the Sun at this day casteth her light. That also is the only means, the true intelligence and correspondence that you ought to haue with his Maiesty, for the augmentation of Gods honour, the contentment and seruice of the King, and the good and peace of his Subiects. Vpon this firme & constant trust, we beseech God to blesse the dayes of your life, to multiply and replenish them with a million of benedictions, and to giue vs grace to yeeld vnto you the proofe of our most humble and most affectioned seruice.

div.head: The names of the Knights of the holy Ghost, which the King made, and which were called by the Herald of the Order, in the Hall of St. German the fift of December. 1619.

list.item: MOnsieur, that is the Kings onely Brother.
The Earle of Soissons, the second, and hitherto the last Prince of the bloud.
The Prince of Ginuile, his brother.
The Duke of Mayenne, their Cousin germane.

The Duke of Elbeuf, their Cousin; these foure of the House of Lorraine, whereof none would weare that Order euer since the Duke of Guise was caused to be killed at Blois, by Henry 3. the Author thereof.
The Duke of Vendosme, the eldest of the base sonnes of Henry 4. Duke of Longueuille.
Duke of Angoulesme, who before was called, Count d'Auuergne, base sonne to Charles the ninth, but now was an beyre to Madame d'Angoulesme, base daughter to Henry.
Duke of Montmorancy, all these being either Princes, or at least Dukes and Peeres.
Duke of Luynes, who is in high fauour with the King: these three, being Dukes, and no Peeres.
The Mareschal of Vitty, sonne to the Lord of Vitry, who dyed in England not long since.
